instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.LCD_BKLT_PWM: What is LCD_BKLT_PWM? LCD_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_DIV: What is LCDBKLT_EN_DIV? LCDBKLT_EN_DIV must be low in order for the P channel MOSFET to have a lower voltage on the gate than is present on the source to allow backlight voltage to flow through the backlight circuit. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
Board came in for no backlight. Found broken pins on J9000 connector. Replaced J9000 but now the backlight is very dim and flickering. Here are some measurements taken

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 27v (so replaced <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>). Still 27v
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> 2.5v (i'm assuming this is suppose to be 3.4v, so replaced <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> after checking for blown resistors or shorts). 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL> - 12.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> 2.5v (i'm assuming this is suppose to be 3.4v"
Why do you suppose that?
There is PWM signal and varies pressing backlight control keys; looks good as DC value.

<CHIP>U9600</CHIP> has firmware, I hope you have used one from same board model.

Did you try known good compatible LCD assembly?

Check for corroded traces and resistors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
Yeah, i had research the chip a little and found that it can come either programmed or not, so replaced it with one from the same version board. 

Tested the display with another board and confirmed that it works.

Had also checked for corrosion and replaced <CAPACITOR>C9010</CAPACITOR> which had corrosion on it, but no shorted. But will will recheck again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
Check continuity from A5/<CHIP>U9701</CHIP> to K/<DIODE>D9701</DIODE>.
Replace <CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR>/99, just in case.
Be sure all return resistors (<RESISTOR>R9717</RESISTOR>-22) are good and post diode mode to ground on the 6 return lines.
Try to reflow and (very) gently tap on <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
Continuity is good 
Replaced <CAPACITOR>C9796</CAPACITOR>/97/99
Return resistors all checkout good and diode mode reading on all is 0.65 at the resistor and at J9000. 
Reflowed <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and also replaced again. 

Backlight is still dim and flickering.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
Check if flickers more on low, or high backlight.
Adjust keys should modify backlight output around 25V.

Change LCD connector, if you've find corrosion near it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
I've replaced the LCD connector twice 

I can get the backlight to work up to about the 5th bar in the backlight intensity level, above that is when it starts to flicker. 
Backlight voltage is about 29v when the brightness intensity is at the 5th bar, once i increase the brightness into the 6th bar, the backlight starts the flicker and the backlight voltage drops to 27v. 

<SIGNAL>LED_RETURN</SIGNAL> are 2.4 when backlight level is set to the 5th bar, and the display is not flickering. Once i increase the backlight to max, the <SIGNAL>LED_RETURN</SIGNAL> drop to 1.8v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
Ooops 15" display, so backlight voltage should be higher; forget about 25V I mentioned before.

Do you have stable <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>?
Try changing <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R9714</RESISTOR> has correct value; also check <RESISTOR>R9716</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
threads.message:
So started looking <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and found something interesting. 

<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV</SIGNAL> - 11.9

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL> - 3.2 at max lcd brightness
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL> - 10.8 at 5 bars lcd brightness level

<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> - 0.05 at max lcd brightness
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> - 2.68 at 5 bars lcd brightness level

On <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>, it should read about 301k (confirmed on a good board), but it's reading 8.9k. I pulled <CAPACITOR>C9782</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> and even <RESISTOR>R0901</RESISTOR>. With all of them pulled, i'm still reading 8.9k across <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Backlight dim and flickering
